title: Part A: Claim
stimulusHtml:
A claim is an arguable statement about a subject.

In this task, students are asked to write a claim based on the rhetorical choice of anecdote. On the summative exam, students will be asked to develop a thesis about the rhetorical choices an author makes in a text to achieve a purpose. While this task is shortened to provide students with practice, the focus of the skills remains the same.

By the end of Unit 1, students should have a fundamental understanding of how to construct an arguable claim about a subject. Students will develop a claim as the last step in this formative free-response practice.

title: Part B: Evidence and Commentary
stimulusHtml:
A piece of information becomes evidence when a writer establishes a logical relationship between the information and a thesis.

Commentary connects the evidence and reasoning to the claim.

In Unit 1, students are asked to identify and explain claims and evidence within an argument. At this point in this course, students are just beginning to develop the skills involved in explaining the relationship between evidence and claims; thus, students are only identifying and explaining one piece of evidence in the free-response practice question. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row when they write full essays in later units and on the summative AP Exam.
